Interestingly, the dummy variable controlling for the existence of a South-South EIA becomes significant, suggesting that South-South integration-long characterized by low complementarities and little trade creation-has significant trade effects in our sample period.

The signature of an EIA involving the harmonization of its standards with the North has a negative and significant impact on its trade with other Southern countries, and the magnitude of the impact is similar to the one appearing in the previous column when it is not interacted with the harmonization dummy (if both are introduced simultaneously, the effect of standards harmonization absorbs that of a NS EIA for the exporter).
